Promote Clean Energy Instead.</title>         <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~r/switchboard_all/~3/jtCg6d9I4Ag/for_nrdc_the_choices_cant.html" />         <id>tag:switchboard.nrdc.org,2015:/blogs/kkennedy//257.18144</id>         <published>2015-03-17T16:15:24Z</published>         <updated>2015-03-17T16:39:03Z</updated>              <summary>             <![CDATA[                 Kit Kennedy, Director of Energy and Transportation, New York:                  For NRDC, the choices can't be clearer or the stakes higher--when there's a conflict between clean energy and fossil fuels, clean energy should always prevail. That's the drama that is playing out right now off the south shore of Long...             ]]>         </summary>         <author>             <name>Kit Kennedy</name>                      </author>              <category term="Curbing Pollution" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#category" />              <category term="Solving Global Warming" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#category" />              <category term="U.S. Law and Policy" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#category" />              <category term="90" label="cleanenergy" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />         <category term="27857" label="libertynaturalgas" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />         <category term="27856" label="lng" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />         <category term="28318" label="longislandnewyorkcityoffshorewindproject" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />         <category term="23751" label="offshorewindpower" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />         <category term="28319" label="portambroselng" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />         <category term="28320" label="uscoastguard" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />         <category term="28322" label="usmaritimeagency" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />                  <content type="html" xml:lang="en-US" xml:base="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/kkennedy/">                              <p>Kit Kennedy, Director of Energy and Transportation, New York</p>                 <p>For NRDC, the choices can't be clearer or the stakes higher--when there's a conflict between clean energy and fossil fuels, clean energy should always prevail. That's the drama that is playing out right now off the south shore of Long Island. There, Liberty Natural Gas, a developer, wants to site a proposed offshore, liquefied natural gas (LNG) import terminal, in the same area as a proposed offshore wind project that has the potential to supply our area with clean wind power. NRDC, like other stakeholders, elected officials and ordinary citizens, submitted <a href="http://docs.nrdc.org/energy/files/ene_15031701a.pdf">comments</a> yesterday and were joined by <a href="http://www.riverkeeper.org">Riverkeeper</a> and <a href="http://www.sierraclub.org">Sierra Club</a> in opposing the LNG terminal. We urge the two federal agencies charged with approving the project permit--the U.S. Department of Transportation's Maritime Administration (MARAD) and the U.S. Coast Guard--to deny the Port Ambrose LNG terminal once and for all. Moreover, New York State and New Jersey should use their authority to veto the project, should the two federal agencies approve it.</p> <p>The federal government, New York State and New Jersey should reject the Port Ambrose project because the facility could prevent forward movement on what could be New York state's first offshore wind project. Instead, the United States, New York state and the region should be working together to build a clean energy future. In fact, it would be the height of irony--and a damaging energy policy--to privilege the construction of a fossil-fuel import facility over a much-needed and long-overdue renewable offshore wind facility that represents a cleaner, healthier future for our children and future generations of New Yorkers.</p> <p>Here are three most important reasons to oppose the Port Ambrose project:</p> <p>First, as I mentioned above, the LNG project conflicts with a pollution-free, offshore wind power project first proposed for the area in 2011 that is wending its way through the siting process and could help <a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/jmorris/why_new_york_needs_a_50_percen.html">New York State get 50 percent of its electricity from renewable sources by 2050</a>;</p> <p>The <a href="http://www.linycoffshorewind.com">Long Island-New York City Offshore Wind Project</a>, proposed by three public and private New York-area utilities--the New York Power Authority (NYPA), the Long Island Power Authority, and Con Edison--would have the capacity to produce 350 megawatts of clean electricity for the overtaxed New York City/Long Island grid. (The project can eventually be expanded to 700 megawatts.) Because offshore wind projects generate the most power when the grid needs it most, on hot summer afternoons and during cold snaps like the ones we've had so many of this winter, this project can significantly improve grid reliability, and, at 350 megawatts, could provide enough electricity to power almost 125,000 homes. Plus, it has great economic development potential. According to <a href="http://www.aertc.org/docs/SBU%20OSW%20Eco%20Dev%20Final%2011-25.pdf">a recent study by experts at SUNY Stonybrook</a>, building a single, 250-megawatt offshore wind power project could create more than 2,800 full-time jobs and add $645 million to the local economy. With a full build-out of New York's offshore wind potential, <a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/kkennedy/with_new_roadmap_new_york_is_p.html">the possibilities are even bigger</a>.</p> <p>Several private developers have also expressed interest in building offshore wind projects on this site. The <a href="http://www.boem.gov">Bureau of Ocean Energy Management</a>, the federal agency responsible for offshore renewable energy programs, has responded favorably to all this interest, collecting both proposals for development and information for an environmental assessment and review of the area that will ultimately result in an auction for leasing rights to build an offshore wind project.<span style="line-height: 1.62;"> </span></p> <p>Though Liberty Natural Gas has called the NYPA offshore wind project and the LNG terminal "compatible uses," they quite simply are not. Here's why: The proposed Port Ambrose project would fall directly inside NYPA's proposed offshore wind lease area. The LNG facility consists of two buoy systems which would receive natural gas from huge LNG vessels and send the gas to land via a pipeline. The LNG carriers would deliver an average of 400 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day. The Port Ambrose facilities are estimated to receive up to 45 deliveries annually, with deliveries taking between 5 and 16 days to complete. According to BOEM, it may be necessary to require a safety zone of almost a mile around the buoy system when the LNG carriers are delivering LNG, for the same reason that a significant buffer is recommended for the wind turbines--to avoid collision and navigational risk.</p> <p>The proposed Port Ambrose LNG facility--and the exclusion zone for the two buoys and the LNG delivery vessels--would be located in the upper third of the NYPA lease site--just the area that is likely best suited for offshore wind turbine siting. Thus, the Port Ambrose facility would not only compete directly with the NYPA offshore wind project for lease space, it would do so in the prime area for offshore wind construction, making construction and operation of the offshore wind project substantially more difficult and expensive, and potentially threatening the viability of the entire project. As BOEM has stated in earlier comments: "the proposal to construct a LNG Port in the same area proposed for a large wind facility could result in serious conflicts--or at the minimum, complicating factors--that may impact the overall viability of one or both projects."</p> <p><a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/kkennedy/Offshore%20wind%20NYPA%20lease%20area%20map.jpg"><img alt="Offshore wind NYPA lease area map.jpg" src="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/kkennedy/assets_c/2015/03/Offshore%20wind%20NYPA%20lease%20area%20map-thumb-500xauto-18973.jpg" width="500" height="384" class="mt-image-center" style="text-align: center; display: block; margin: 0 auto 20px;" /></a><em style="line-height: 1.62;">As this map indicates, the proposed Port Ambrose LNG terminal would conflict with an offshore wind power project proposed in 2011 and now moving through the siting process.</em></p> <p>Second, there's no need for the Port Ambrose LNG project. As NRDC's comments explain, the very concept of building an LNG import facility is out-dated U.S. energy policy. These days, the United States has a natural gas glut. Exports have displaced imports, with numerous export facilities proposed; many import facilities remain underutilized. Moreover, by scaling up energy efficiency programs and renewable energy options, including offshore wind and on-site, clean, distributed energy sources such as solar power, we can more easily, quickly and cheaply meet the peak load and power needs of New York and Long Island. That's the vision of New York's emerging <a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/jmorris/rev-ing_it_up_in_new_york_a_lo.html">Reforming Energy Vision policy</a>, and Port Ambrose just doesn't fit in.</p> <p>Finally, as residents of Long Island, New York and New Jersey know only too well from our experiences with Superstorm Sandy, now is not the time to increase our dependence on dirty fossil fuels that will further disturb our climate, especially when clean alternatives like energy efficiency and renewable energy are available. What the New York and Long Island area need now to help meet our energy needs is not more dangerous fossil fuels but the clean energy that offshore wind power, on-land wind, solar power, and energy efficiency can provide.</p> <p>MARAD and the Coast Guard can only approve the Port Ambrose project if they determine that "the construction and operation of the deepwater [LNG project] will be in the national interest and consistent with national security and other national policy goals and objectives, including energy sufficiency and environmental quality." The Port Ambrose LNG facility most decidedly does not.</p>                                       <div class="feedflare"> <a href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~ff/switchboard_all?a=jtCg6d9I4Ag:b0q0nBHSr1I:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/switchboard_all?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~ff/switchboard_all?a=jtCg6d9I4Ag:b0q0nBHSr1I:dnMXMwOfBR0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/switchboard_all?d=dnMXMwOfBR0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~ff/switchboard_all?a=jtCg6d9I4Ag:b0q0nBHSr1I:bcOpcFrp8Mo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/switchboard_all?d=bcOpcFrp8Mo" border="0"></img></a> </div><img src="//feeds.feedburner.com/~r/switchboard_all/~4/jtCg6d9I4Ag" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content>     <feedburner:origLink>http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/kkennedy/for_nrdc_the_choices_cant.html</feedburner:origLink></entry>          <entry>         <title type="html">While state officials fight it, North Carolina continues down Clean Power path</title>         <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~r/switchboard_all/~3/WnwqCcZvoPI/while_state_officials_fight_it.html" />         <id>tag:switchboard.nrdc.org,2015:/blogs/lmartinez//52.18143</id>         <published>2015-03-17T13:02:33Z</published>         <updated>2015-03-17T13:42:04Z</updated>            <summary>             <![CDATA[                 Luis Martinez, Senior Attorney, Energy and Transportation Program, Asheville, North Carolina:                  New analysis by the Natural Resource Defense Council shows that North Carolina's Clean Energy Future is strong. <content type="html" xml:lang="en-US" xml:base="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/lmartinez/">                              <p>Luis Martinez, Senior Attorney, Energy and Transportation Program, Asheville, North Carolina</p>                 <p>New analysis by the Natural Resource Defense Council shows that <a href="http://www.nrdc.org/globalwarming/files/clean-power-plan-state-options-NC.pdf">North Carolina's Clean Energy Future</a> is strong. Our analysis shows that by continuing its transition away from coal and meeting the requirements of its clean energy standard, North Carolina will achieve about 90% of the reductions required by the Clean Power Plan with nine years left until the 2030 deadline. And renewed commitment to energy efficiency and renewable energy will help the state achieve the goals while generating more jobs and less pollution. So while some naysayers, including the head of North Carolina's Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NC DENR), continue to work actively to derail the plan, it will help the state continue on a path it set for itself well over a decade ago.</p> <p>The <a href="http://www2.epa.gov/carbon-pollution-standards/clean-power-plan-proposed-rule">Clean Power Plan</a> from the Environmental Protection Agency limits carbon emissions from power plants with the goal of curbing climate change by transitioning towards clean energy. It sets pollution reduction targets and gives states both ample time and plenty of flexibility to achieve those goals. In North Carolina, as I've written <a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/lmartinez/north_carolina_off_to_a_great.html">before</a>, we started down this path a long time ago with the introduction of the Clean Smokestacks Act. That Act was very similar to the Clean Power Plan, in that it set pollution reduction goals and gave the utilities plenty of time and flexibility to meet them. The result is that, over a decade later, sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions from power plants have decreased over 80% without any electric reliability impacts and with significant <a href="https://nicholasinstitute.duke.edu/sites/default/files/publications/ni_wp_12-05.pdf">economic and health benefits</a>.</p> <p>Additionally, North Carolina continued its journey towards clean energy by requiring utilities to source an increasing share of their electricity from clean energy sources. The <a href="http://www.ncuc.commerce.state.nc.us/reps/reps.htm">Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Portfolio Standard</a> put the state in a path towards having 12.5% of the electricity in North Carolina come from renewable energy or energy efficiency by 2021. Yet again the state is well on its way to meeting this goal with plenty of time left and with significant economic and health benefits. As a new Duke University <a href="http://www.cggc.duke.edu/pdfs/02152015Duke_CGGC_NCSolarEnergyReport.pdf">report</a> tells us the economic benefits from solar energy are significant and widespread. Additionally, North Carolina has become <a href="http://www.seia.org/news/north-carolina-leads-south-2nd-nation-new-solar-installations">a leader</a> in that industry ranking second, behind only California for installed solar capacity in 2014. The state also moved into fourth place nationally on total installed solar capacity, only behind California, Arizona and New Jersey. And the state also ranks in eight place nationally in total <a href="http://www.bizjournals.com/charlotte/blog/energy/2015/03/top-ten-five-ways.html">solar jobs</a>.</p> <p>And yet today, like he did back in <a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/lmartinez/north_carolina_has_a_choice_on.html">November of 2013</a>, Donald van der Vaart, now head of North Carolina's Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NC DENR), will go before the House Energy and Commerce <a href="http://energycommerce.house.gov/hearing/epa%E2%80%99s-proposed-111d-rule-existing-power-plants-legal-and-cost-issues">Committee</a> of the US Congress and do <a href="http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF03/20150317/103073/HHRG-114-IF03-Wstate-vanderVaartD-20150317.pdf">his part to stop</a> the Environmental Protection Agency from moving forward on the Clean Power Plan. But North Carolina began this journey towards a strong clean energy economy well over a decade ago. Read more about it on <a href="http://saferchemicals.org/2015/03/13/nations-1-furniture-retailer-banning-toxic-flame-retardant-chemicals/">Mind the Store's blog</a>. Even better, Ashley announced that ALL of their new furniture, no matter where in the country, will comply with <a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/tagging_toxics_legislation_gre.html">California's new labeling law</a>, so shoppers can easily tell which couches contain toxic flame retardant chemicals and which ones don't.</p> <p>Signed by Governor Brown last year, the CA labeling law requires all upholstered furniture (like couches, sofas, loveseats, and recliners) manufactured after January 1, 2015 to have a label that states whether or not harmful flame retardant chemicals were added to the product.</p> <p>Simple, right? Well, the new label is easy to understand, but unfortunately the situation is more complicated when you go into a furniture store. Some stores are ahead of the game and are already offering products without these unnecessary and harmful chemicals. (These stores are listed in our <a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/buying_a_safer_sofa_nrdc_surve.html">furniture store survey</a> and also covered in a recent article from the <a href="http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/watchdog/ct-flame-retardants-furniture-20150123-story.html#page=1">Chicago Tribune</a>.) But not all the couches in stores will have the simple flame retardant label yet. That's because the labeling law <span style="text-decoration: underline;">only</span> applies to new furniture that's manufactured this year. Couches made in 2014 or earlier have different labels and may or may not contain flame retardants.</p> <p>So, what do you need to look for before you buy?</p> <p style="text-align: center;">First, find the flammability/ law label attached to the furniture. It's usually located underneath the furniture or under the cushions.<a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/SB%201019%20update%20blog%20pictures.jpg"><img alt="SB 1019 update blog pictures.jpg" src="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/assets_c/2015/02/SB%201019%20update%20blog%20pictures-thumb-500xauto-18694.jpg" class="mt-image-center" style="text-align: center; display: block; margin: 0 auto 20px;" height="359" width="567" /></a></p> <p style="text-align: center;"></p> <p style="text-align: center;">Here are the <b>three different kinds of labels you could see and what they mean:</b></p> <p style="text-align: center;"></p> <p style="color: #fff;">_</p> <h1 style="text-align: center;">#1</h1> <p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/Best%20label.jpg"><img alt="Best label.jpg" src="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/assets_c/2015/02/Best%20label-thumb-500xauto-18702.jpg" class="mt-image-center" style="text-align: center; display: block; margin: 0 auto 0px;" height="446" width="595" /></a><small><b>Best</b>: Flammability requirements label followed by the flame retardant label. Look for flame retardant labels marked "contain NO added flame retardant chemicals."</small></p> <p style="text-align: center;">You may be able to special order these products if they are not in stores yet.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"></p> <p style="color: #fff;">_</p> <h1 style="text-align: center;">#2</h1> <p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/questions%20label%202.jpg"><img alt="questions label 2.jpg" src="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/assets_c/2015/02/questions%20label%202-thumb-500xauto-18718.jpg" class="mt-image-center" style="text-align: center; display: block; margin: 0 auto 0px;" height="212" width="500" /></a><small><b>Ask questions</b>: Flammability requirements label with "<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Technical Bulletin 117-<b>2013</b></span>" or "<span style="text-decoration: underline;">TB117-<b>2013</b></span>." These products may or may not contain flame retardant chemicals. Ask the store or check with the manufacturer.</small></p> <p style="text-align: center;"></p> <p style="color: #fff;">_</p> <h1 style="text-align: center;">#3</h1> <p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/worst%20label%203.jpg"><img alt="worst label 3.jpg" src="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/vsingla/assets_c/2015/02/worst%20label%203-thumb-500xauto-18720.jpg" class="mt-image-center" style="text-align: center; display: block; margin: 0 auto 0px;" height="237" width="500" /></a><small><b>Worst</b>: Flammability requirements label with "<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Technical Bulletin 117</span>" or "<span style="text-decoration: underline;">TB117</span>." These products almost certainly contain flame retardants.</small></p> <hr /> <p>As brand new products hit stores later this year, you'll be able to see more and more with the simple flame retardant term="28315" label="mitchmcconnell" scheme="http://www.sixapart.com/ns/types#tag" />                  <content type="html" xml:lang="en-US" xml:base="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/ddoniger/">                              <p>David Doniger, Director, Climate and Clean Air Program, Washington, D.C.</p>                 <p>The nation's governors aren't rushing to heed Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's call for states to "<a href="http://www.kentucky.com/2015/03/03/3725288_states-should-reject-obama-mandate.html?rh=1">just say no</a>" to the <a href="http://www2.epa.gov/carbon-pollution-standards/clean-power-plan-proposed-rule">Clean Power Plan</a>, which would put the first-ever Clean Air Act limits on the two billion tons of climate-changing carbon pollution coming from our power plants.</p> <p>The number one goal of Sen. McConnell's big polluter agenda is blocking the Clean Power Plan, the centerpiece of President Obama's climate action initiatives. McConnell wants states to blow off the Clean Air Act by refusing to write a state plan.</p> <p>McConnell's call has startled many observers. Former New Jersey Governor Christie Todd Whitman, who served as President George W. Bush's first EPA administrator, wrote in <i><a href="https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=http-3A__www.politico.com_magazine_story_2015_03_mitch-2Dmcconnell-2Depa-2D116093.html-3Fml-3Dtl-5F20-23.VQdtrU1OVjq&amp;d=AwMFAg&amp;c=QbuapHRvbn0JdC8vTVkPHg&amp;r=lJ-2xIfZf5VMP4SUJ1ovwg8Aa8Z-wgM5d2FJWIthilc&amp;m=QPHrIarxGp9QLFVbJTdyFRUWtfc7dy56Do-aPS9IUrQ&amp;s=nWSf1Y2GVKPQEKM07Md9jD0wMwVs8C7IRTP2CO-y0J8&amp;e=">Politico</a> </i>yesterday that McConnell "cannot and should not call on others to ignore a law." And power company executives are afraid of being <a href="http://wyomingpublicmedia.org/post/utilities-say-collaboration-creativity-key-clean-power-plan">caught in a political squeeze without a back-up plan</a>.</p> <p>Not a single governor has stepped forward to take McConnell's pledge. And there are good reasons. More and more states are awakening to the attractive clean energy options that will curb carbon pollution while building their economies, creating new jobs, and saving consumers billions on their electric bills. For the latest example, read <a href="http://www.michigan.gov/documents/150313_Energy_Message_FINAL_484033_7.pdf">Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder's energy message</a> last week, which sets ambitious clean energy goals for his state.</p> <p>And governors know that if they don't write a plan to clean up their power plants, the law requires the Environmental Protection Agency to do it. So the irony is that in urging states to say no, McConnell is calling for a transfer of authority and control from the states to Washington. That's not what Republicans usually recommend.</p> <p>Bear with me now for a quick explanation of how the Clean Air Act works. Since President Richard Nixon signed this landmark law in 1970, we've recognized that air pollution is a national problem. It doesn't stop at state borders. Both states and businesses need national minimum requirements that keep unscrupulous businesses from playing states off against one another and from undercutting responsible companies.</p> <p>At the same time, for 45 years the Clean Air Act has recognized states' leading role in shaping clean air plans to meet those federal limits.</p> <p>This sharing of federal and state responsibilities is called "cooperative federalism," and it has been widely used since the New Deal. The Clean Air Act charges EPA with setting national standards for reducing dangerous air pollutants. The Act then gives the states the first option to regulate the sources of that pollution by adopting a state plan - a package of state pollution limits - which EPA approves if it will meet the applicable standard. The law tells EPA to stand in reserve, ready to regulate those sources directly through a federal plan if a state fails to adopt an approvable state plan.</p> <p>Cooperative federalism does not force the states to regulate. Rather, it respects states' important role by giving them the first opportunity to shape specific pollution control plans to meet national pollution targets in the way that best meet local circumstances. The federal role is as back-up, to regulate the pollution sources directly only if a state fails to do so.</p> <p>For more than four decades, states have almost always taken the opportunity that the Clean Air Act offers them. Federal plans have been needed only rarely, and usually only briefly until the states take back the lead.</p> <p>Congress does not have to proceed this way. Indeed, important parts of the Clean Air Act tell EPA to regulate power plants directly, with no state role - for example, to curb acid rain and cut toxic air pollutants. But cooperative federalism is the way Congress chose to go 45 years ago in the part of the Clean Air Act that covers pollutants like carbon dioxide from existing power plants, called Section 111(d). States get the first shot; the federal government steps in to regulate pollution sources - not to regulate the state - only if the state fails to act.</p> <p>The Supreme Court recognized EPA's authority to curb power plants' carbon pollution through this cooperative model in 2011, in a case called <a href="https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/10-174.ZO.htmlhttps:/www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/10-174.ZO.html"><i>American Electric Power v. Connecticut</i></a><i>. </i>EPA's Clean Power Plan follows the prescribed approach by setting carbon pollution targets tailored to the characteristics of the power sector in each state, and asking each state to develop its own plan.</p> <p>Back to McConnell's call for inaction. Governors aren't saying no because they, their power companies, and many other state stakeholders recognize that when the state writes its own plan, it has opportunities to tailor those pollution limits to best fit local circumstances. If a state drops the ball, the federal government must develop a federal pollution plan for that state.</p> <p>EPA will propose and take comment on a federal plan this summer, when it finalizes the state targets after considering nearly four million comments. Almost certainly, the proposed federal plan will establish pollution limits that apply directly to the carbon-emitting power plants in a given state. Far from an onerous bogeyman, the federal plan will be affordable and flexible. It will allow sources to comply by directly reducing their emissions or by obtaining credits from actions across the electricity system that reduce carbon pollution, from generating electricity at cleaner or zero-emitting plants to reducing electricity demand (and therefore generation and pollution) by making homes, factories, and other businesses more energy-efficient. This federal plan will regulate the power plants, not the state, and it will come into play only if a state doesn't adopt an approvable state plan of its own.</p> <p>State leaders, power companies, and other stakeholders aren't rushing to get on McConnell's bandwagon because they know states have even more tools at their at their command than EPA - tools that can help do the job in the way that best fits their state. For example, states can adopt supplementary clean energy policies to promote renewables and efficiency, and they can help site transmission lines, etc. - steps that can further reduce costs and promote productive investments.</p> <p>In short, federal plans will be flexible and affordable, but states can create individualized plans that will work even better. Federal plans good, state plans better.</p> <p>That's why power companies in many states have been working to kill or defang state legislation that would block states from adopting their own plans, or box states into high-cost approaches. For instance, in the recent session of the Virginia General Assembly, Dominion Resources quietly helped kill bills that would have obstructed the state from writing its own plan. In Kentucky, one of the largest power companies is openly raising <a href="http://www.eenews.net/energywire/stories/1060014722">the need to revisit a restrictive law</a> adopted there last year. And Berkshire Hathaway Energy is urging states to <a href="http://wyomingpublicmedia.org/post/utilities-say-collaboration-creativity-key-clean-power-plan">make sure power companies have a back-up plan</a> that they can meet.</p> <p>To be sure, some governors will join legal challenges when EPA finalizes the Clean Power Plan. But legal challenges are a long shot, so they are also very likely to hedge their bets by continuing to work on state plans, using all the clean energy options that the Clean Power Plan incorporates.</p> <p>As for Sen. McConnell, he will try to pass legislation to block the plan. But he is unlikely to garner the 60 votes needed to pass such a bill in the Senate, and even less likely to get the 67 votes needed to override President Obama's veto. So he will continue to rage against EPA and urge governors to say no. Just don't expect too many to jump on the bandwagon.</p>                                       <div class="feedflare"> <a href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~ff/switchboard_all?a=D3iybudS1xE:50Jpq3QeUEg:yIl2AUoC8zA"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/switchboard_all?d=yIl2AUoC8zA" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~ff/switchboard_all?a=D3iybudS1xE:50Jpq3QeUEg:dnMXMwOfBR0"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/switchboard_all?d=dnMXMwOfBR0" border="0"></img></a> <a href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~ff/switchboard_all?a=D3iybudS1xE:50Jpq3QeUEg:bcOpcFrp8Mo"><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/switchboard_all?d=bcOpcFrp8Mo" border="0"></img></a> </div><img src="//feeds.feedburner.com/~r/switchboard_all/~4/D3iybudS1xE" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content>     <feedburner:origLink>http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/ddoniger/why_states_arent_rushing_to_ju.html</feedburner:origLink></entry>          <entry>         <title type="html">Cutting Carbon Pollution: Florida's Opportunity to Shine</title>         <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://rss.nrdcfeeds.org/~r/switchboard_all/~3/uQLjElIKbsU/cutting_carbon_pollution_flori.html" />         <id>tag:switchboard.nrdc.org,2015:/blogs/privera//411.18142</id>         <published>2015-03-17T11:43:46Z</published>         <updated>2015-03-17T18:05:24Z</updated>              <summary>             <![CDATA[                 Pamela Rivera, Partnership and Constituency Advocate, Center for Policy Advocacy, Washington, D.C.:                   If there is something we know in Florida it's that protecting the beauty of our state's natural resources is a no-brainer. 20px;" /></a></p> <p>If there is something we know in Florida <span style="line-height: 1.62;">it's that protecting the beauty of our </span><span style="line-height: 1.62;">state's </span><span style="line-height: 1.62;">natural resources is a no-brainer. Our children play in the springs </span><span style="line-height: 1.62;">in the summer and </span><span style="line-height: 1.62;">build sandcastles on the beach in the fall. In many ways we live in paradise, which is </span><span style="line-height: 1.62;">why protecting it for future generations is crucial. Climate change is a very clear and </span><span style="line-height: 1.62;">present danger in Florida and it </span><span style="line-height: 1.62;">threatens our economy that is so closely tied to </span><span style="line-height: 1.62;">our beautiful beaches and incredible wildlife.</span></p> <p>In Florida, nearly half of the state's nearly 19 million residents live less than one meter above the local Mean High Water, which is the average of all the high water heights observed by the National Tidal Datum Epoch. Even a few inches of sea level rise can pose a major threat to areas in southeast Florida and in fact, we have seen many wells in that part of the state close due to contamination from sea level rise.</p> <p>Climate change is happening. So where does that leave us? We have ideas in a new state primer for Florida released today, and I'll discuss some of them <a href="http://www.nrdc.org/globalwarming/files/clean-power-plan-state-options-FL.pdf">here</a>.</p> <p>The single biggest source of carbon pollution in the U.S. comes from fossil-fuel power plants. They account for nearly 40 percent of U.S. carbon pollution. Currently, we limit mercury, lead and soot from these power plants, but not carbon pollution. This is just crazy and thankfully, it is changing. On June 2, 2014, the EPA proposed the Clean Power Plan, which sets the first-ever standards limiting carbon pollution. The plan, when in place, would <a href="http://www.nrdc.org/energy/clean-energy-benefits-vulnerable-communities.asp">prevent</a> about 550 million metric tons of carbon dioxide nationwide by 2030 and prevents 2,700 to 6,600 premature deaths. That is HUGE!</p> <p>Under the EPA's plan every state has the opportunity to craft its own best strategy to reduce pollution and protect our climate. Investing in energy efficiency and renewable solar and wind power should be a fundamental part of Florida's strategy.</p> <p>We have seen that ramping up energy efficiency programs can create <a href="http://www.nrdc.org/air/pollution-standards/state-benefits.asp">10,000 new jobs</a> in Florida and because using energy efficiency allows us to do more with less power, we can save more money on our electric bills!</p> <p>We aren't known as the Sunshine State for nothing, Florida ranks third in solar potential, but is currently lagging and a lot of that comes from the lack of programs in state to help facilitate that growth. Energy efficiency and renewable energy are zero-carbon, low cost options that will help meet Florida's goals as it plans for the Clean Power Plan.</p> <p>Everyone knows Florida summers come fast and stay a while and that causes extensive use of air conditioning, which has a lot to do with why the <a href="http://www.eia.gov/state/print.cfm?sid=FL">average</a> Florida household spend $1,900 every year on electricity--40 percent more than the U.S. average.</p> <p>Florida is well-positioned to meet its carbon pollution target while expanding its clean energy portfolio<b>--</b>and should also continue to discuss potential collaboration with neighboring states under the Clean Power Plan. In many cases, a region multi-state approach to compliance is cheaper than states going it alone, as described in this <a href="http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/syeh/pjm_regional_cooperation_leads.htmlhttp:/switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/syeh/pjm_regional_cooperation_leads.html">post</a> from my colleague Starla Yeh, and further highlighted in this excellent<b> </b><a href="http://www.analysisgroup.com/uploadedFiles/Publishing/Articles/Electric_System_Reliability_and_EPAs_Clean_Power_Plan_Case_of_PJM.pdf"><b>Analysis Group report</b></a><b>. </b>Our energy future rests in our hands. The Clean Power Plan presents us with a wonderful opportunity to move forward. Let's do it together.
